channel.title: Hacker News - English
channel.description: Hacker News articles summarized and translated to English

item.title: iPod Socks
item.description:
Apple Special Music Event 2004 (Speech). ^ Apple removes iPod Socks from online store, AppleInsider. "Review: Apple iPod Socks".

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 23 Comments:

robertlagrant:

I need some AirPod mittens to keep my collection in.

Manfred:

I also had an iPad sock, that eventually fitted an MacBook Air.

sphars:

Context for this submission:

Apple releases the iPhone Pocket: https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2025/11/introducing-iphone-po...

HN discussion: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45885813

hhh:

It sucks that most people don’t see the pocket as the perfect overlap between fashion and tech. It’s the ideal Issey Miyake bag, it’s just something tech people won’t get.

jimnotgym:

I always have a little chuckle when I see people holding a tiny delicate smartphone in a massive fat case to protect it from the damage it will inevitably take in normal use. I always think that it would have been better if they had just made the phone itself a little tougher!

xg15:

> They were available in a package of six different colors, including green, purple, grey, blue, orange and pink, for US$29.

> Horwitz [...] criticized the socks for [...] high price.

> Apple stopped selling the product sometime in September 2012. The set soon became a collector's item, with aftermarket prices rising as high as US$90 by 2014.

It didn't have a strap though. The strap is clearly worth the additional $200.95!

thesurlydev:

vom

dinobones:

$30 for a sock even in 2025 seems pretty steep. In 2004 is crazy. I guess I'm forgetting how "overpriced" Apple was at the time.

reconnecting:

I'm wondering if there are Socks/Pocket for Apple Vision Pro planned for release in 2035.

sph:

The world wasn't ready for this. Apple is living two decades ahead.

dabluecaboose:

After recently fixing up and using my old iPod, I was happy to find the website that I used to buy my parts also sells generic iPod socks!

I've got one on it in my phone locker right now.

https://eoe.works/collections/cases-attachments/products/new...

golden-face:

Stuff like this was kind of necessary on those early generation iPods, they had mechanical spinning disks. I remember dropping mine and hearing the click from the busted disk :/

rambambram:

Back when smartphones were not a thing yet, I had some new Nokia model that I kept in a little fabric 'bag' that I got with my Minidisc-player. I remember being laughed at by some friends. Years later everybody uses some kind of case for their smartphone, and I go by some personal policy to keep the bare smartphone in my pocket. I don't know why I tell this, maybe because I sometimes feel like a trendsetter.

delBarrio:

used one with my magic mouse 1, never would have paid upwards of $40 for it. was quite handy tho, to avoid scratching the delicate white plastic, despite it barely fit. Issey Myake knit lanyard pocket -- what a joke! Buckle up folks, we're definitely in a bubble.

jasongill:

I didn't realize these were a collectors item, I had bought a couple packs as they worked great to keep the iPod from clattering around in the glove compartment or center console of the car. I gave some to friends who used them as phone cases in the early iPhone days.

Isamu:

I bought these for the kids, back in the iPod days. Fun and helpful to keep the things from getting too banged up. But actually the iPod era went by quickly.

The iPod was a stepping stone to the iPhone but even Steve didn’t know that at the beginning.

stevekemp:

Back in the day I knitted something similar for myself, though I don't recall if I'd seen the original product.

In fact earlier this year I bought a new kindle and knitted a little "sock" for it:

https://www.instagram.com/p/DGTsi5SM9YM/

Just knit a rectangle, and sew two edges together to make a flat "sock" or "envelope". I was done in a couple of hours, but I guess I'm used to knitting in front of the TV.

shmeeed:

I love that these posts are right below each other at the moment.

tetris11:

> Apple stopped selling the product sometime in September 2012.[5] The set soon became a collector's item, with aftermarket prices rising as high as US$90 by 2014.

There it is. The only reason anyone on HN will ever give a damn

jsheard:

Apple releases a baffling knitted thing every 20 years. What wonders will 2045 bring?

Alir3z4:

I never ever knew such product existed.

No wonder they made iPhone pocket now.

They should make tshirts for their laptops as well.

swiftcoder:

Who knew Apple had a long history of knitwear releases?

rekabis:

Holy shite. I never knew. Or, at least, this rings no bells. I have several iPod classics, now I know what to look for on eBay.

item.title: Cache-Friendly, Low-Memory Lanczos Algorithm in Rust
item.description:
The standard Lanczos method for computing matrix functions has a brutal memory requirement: storing an n×kn \times kn×k basis matrix that grows with every iteration. Indeed, there are a lot problems with computing f(A)f(\mathbf{A})f(A) directly. We need an orthonormal basis.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 1 Comments:

sfpotter:

Nice result! Arnoldi is a beautiful algorithm, and this is a good application of it.

What are you using this for and why are you working on it?

I admit I'm not personally convinced of the value of Rust in numerics, but that's just me, I guess...

item.title: Show HN: Cactoide – Federated RSVP Platform
item.description:
Share your public events and create a decentralized event discovery network. Create Event Fill out a simple form with event details. Ready to Create Your First Event.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 3 Comments:

mrtesthah:

How does it compare to Mobilizon?

righthand:

This is cool looking but you should note in the front page that it has ical, et al. calendar features.

andy_ppp:

Very cool, is it possible to add voting for multiple dates too?

item.title: We ran over 600 image generations to compare AI image models
item.description:
Blog tl:dr; We’ve been making photo apps for iOS for long enough that we have gray hairs now, and using our experience we ran over 600 image generations to compare which AI models work best for which image edits. With the release of newer models like nanoBanana and Seedream, we’ve had to consider which models make sense to support. Image generation times are also relevant.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 2 Comments:

jstummbillig:

> If you made it all the way down here you probably don’t need a summary

Love the optimism

Dwedit:

You can always identify the OpenAI result because it's yellow.

item.title: Weave (YC W25) is hiring a founding ML engineer
item.description:
You must also be pragmatic. You must be empathetic. You must care about helping other software engineering teams be great.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

item.title: Drawing Text Isn't Simple: Benchmarking Console vs. Graphical Rendering
item.description:
Drawing Text on Screen - What Could Be Simpler. Some watch movies, some read, some play with flashcards, others just jump into deep water and start talking with zero vocabulary. Even with optimizations.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 8 Comments:

henning:

Caching the fonts to a texture atlas is not an unusual idea. https://github.com/memononen/fontstash is a well known example of this. Odin has a native port meant to work in conjunction with its bindings to NanoVG. The Odin code is coupled to stb_freetype.

JodieBenitez:

And another website made unusable thanks to inconsiderate use of javascript.

cluckindan:

I wonder how the GPU version is implemented. One quad and one texture draw per glyph sounds very not scalable, but one quad per terminal, one texture atlas and one shader to draw glyphs from the atlas already sounds much better.

unwind:

Meta: this is kind of a repost, not even a month since last time [1].

[1]: https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=45580559

jayd16:

Stupid question but what are the units used in the results tables??

bob1029:

SDF seems to be one of the better solutions for text rendering.

Valve had this problem solved since 2007. I'd argue this technique is a big part of what gave TF2 its impressive visual style. That game ran at 100+ fps on hardware like the 8800GT at the time.

https://www.redblobgames.com/x/2403-distance-field-fonts/

9999_points:

This is "an entire doctoral research project in performant terminal emulation".

https://github.com/microsoft/terminal/issues/10362#issuecomm...

krstffr:

This website almost crashed my m1 macbook pro (renders at 1 fps or something), so I guess point taken: rendering text is not simple!

item.title: Firefox expands fingerprint protections
item.description:
your graphics hardware information, which allows sites to optimize games for your computer. Since 2021, Firefox has been incrementally advancing fingerprinting protections, covering the most pervasive fingerprinting techniques. The goal: strong privacy protections that don’t get in your way.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 13 Comments:

Fokamul:

I dev my private fork of browser fingerprinting bypass and I can tell, this is like 1% of what commercial tracking companies use for fingerprinting.

Unless they tackle all the hidden things, all artifacts, canvas rendering and many more.

These companies will be actually happy after this change, because even users with ublock and other plugins, will think they're not tracked. Yeah, nope.

And it's not that hard to see how they fingerprint your browser, reverse any JS tracking script yourself and see.

instagib:

One thing I found that broke tracking algorithms was the ‘every tab is a new random profile’ extension. I can’t remember the name as I haven’t used it in a while and it broke a lot of logins.

They could not build a profile on you and it would break their system of tracking user login per device.

Bender:

On the topic of Firefox fingerprinting, how does one edit the NetworkID in about:networking#networkid without creating new profiles or user accounts?

nalekberov:

Fingerprinting is nearly impossible to resist these days anyways, no matter which technics Firefox uses to reduce it, and sometimes it actually makes the browser appear more unique.

Last time I tried everything I could to prevent Firefox from calling home, it was still requesting Mozilla servers. Though I haven’t given up, my plan is disabling it at source code level and build my own release.

charcircuit:

>Having a unique fingerprint means fingerprinters can continuously identify you invisibly

This is not right. If you have a unique fingerprint every time someone tries to fingerprint you, then they have to do extra work to try and figure out which are the same. If you make it always be the same you've made the fingerprinter's job much easier.

shevy-java:

I tested firefox recently. It had some AI summary button or something that was new. I instantly wanted to eliminate this from the UI but I don't know how to do that. I guess it is possible? But it probably requires some time and research; the thing I don't need or want this, it just takes away space.

Then I remembered why I no longer use firefox. I believe we, as users, need to take back the open web. The days of some random developers ruining the UI should really be over, be it firefox, or Google chrome killing ublock origin. We need to fight back.

dmix:

I use FF and I paid for NYTimes. I was logged in, yet NYTimes constantly flagged my browser with a persistent captcha I couldn't bypass for months (across 2 different machines). It thought I was a bot because of the privacy features. So I cancelled my subscription using my phone.

y-c-o-m-b:

I exclusively use private browsing, but I know that doesn't do much in preventing tracking, so it's nice to see this finally starting to roll out.

The fact that I have to go to great lengths to browse anonymously - and companies desperately try to circumvent my genuine decision to opt out of their tracking - tells me everything I need to know about those companies. Words like sleezy, shady, and predatory come to mind.

I would love to see this taken one step further and have states/countries prevent companies from tracking me altogether if I reject their cookies, but I fear it's more likely those companies will lobby to prevent Firefox from protecting us.

cluckindan:

It’s a bit annoying that Firefox by default breaks all sites that use canvas imageData API. There is no permission for that, so no user-friendly way to ask for consent either.

xnx:

This is a good use of Firefox resources. Unfortunately Firefox is at a natural disadvantage for fingerprinting by virtue of being used by such a small number of users.

pona-a:

I wish them the best. When I last tested it on fingerprint.com, the hash remained stable even with resistFingerprinting and letterboxing from a VPN, only changing between profiles. When I daily-drove resistFingerprinting (not reduceFingerprinting that permits exceptions like dark mode) in 2021, my hash changed every restart.

Dwedit:

Adding noise to images sounds like a really bad idea. It will mess with any Javascript code which performs processing on images. Try writing a photo editor in Javascript and watch your browser corrupt your images.

tmtvl:

I'm already using CanvasBlocker, Decentraleyes, and the NoScript Security Suite; but getting more protections will be nice. Even if it may take a while for them to land in Waterfox.

item.title: Pikaday: A friendly guide to front-end date pickers
item.description:
Date input Date The date input type provides a native date picker. Datetime input Date and time The datetime-local input type combines both date and time. UK date input component.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 1 Comments:

carlosjobim:

They are wrong. Most OS native date pickers are very bad from a usability perspective. A javascript date picker fixes these issues, and allows more functions.

And why are they arguing against their own product? Even making up bogus claims that using js date pickers would be illegal in Europe?

item.title: Grebedoc – static site hosting for Git forges
item.description:
After using Method A or Method B, configure your domain to have A/AAAA records pointing to the same server as grebedoc. This configuration method is not limited to Codeberg; it works with any Forgejo, Gitea, Gogs, or GitHub based forge. Next, configure your forge or Git repository to issue a PUT HTTP request after a branch has been updated with this Curl command (or its equivalent): For Method A: curl http://{domain}/ -X PUT --data "https://{forge}/{repo}.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 1 Comments:

jszymborski:

Easter egg: The favicon is an upside down Codeberg logo.

Am I understanding correctly that this is Codeberg pages, but for git repos that are not necessarily (but especially designed for those which are) hosted on Codeberg?

item.title: Blender 5.1
item.description:
1 Release Notes¶ Blender 5. Under development in main. Animation & Rigging Assets Compositor Core Cycles EEVEE & Viewport Geometry Nodes Grease Pencil Modeling & UV Motion Tracking Physics Pipeline & I/O Python API Rendering Sculpt, Paint, Texture User Interface Video Sequencer Compatibility¶.

HN Discussion

Read Original Article

Top 5 Comments:

NSUserDefaults:

Insane velocity. The UI is fantastic, would love to see more tools reuse it, like a DAW or a proper dedicated CAD app but from what I read it is deeply integrated in the project.

glimshe:

Every time Blender releases an update, I think: the two most amazing open source projects of all time are Linux and Blender.

boriskourt:

https://developer.blender.org/docs/release_notes/5.0/

5.0 is about to drop, maybe you wanted to share that?

dcrazy:

> Blender 5.1 is currently in Alpha until February 4, 2026.

embedding-shape:

Very much early for this, it's still Alpha, and the release notes there aren't even complete yet either. I'd say wait until the official stable release at least, which will get a proper landing page highlighting all the changes in a much better way.
